qas.question: Why were vegetal green dyes less than ideal?

answers.text: they rapidly faded or changed color

qas.question: When was a good green vegetal dye finally produced?
Vegetal dyes were good at resisting what?
What is another name for woad?
When did people begin using the leaves of the fraxinus for green dyes?
What color did green-dyed clothes often change to?
Which part of the digitalis plant was used to create green dye?

context: Unfortunately for those who wanted or were required to wear green, there were no good vegetal green dyes which resisted <b3_0>washing and sunlight<b3_0/>. Green dyes were made out of the fern, plantain, buckthorn berries, <b7_0>the juice<b7_0/> of nettles and of leeks, the digitalis plant, the broom plant, the leaves of the fraxinus, or ash tree, and the bark of the alder tree, but <a0_0>they rapidly faded or changed color<a0_0/>. Only in <b5_0>the <a1_0>16th century<b5_0/><a1_0/> was a good green dye produced, by first dyeing the cloth <b6_0>blue<b6_0/> with woad, and then yellow with <a2_0>reseda luteola<a2_0/>, also known as <b4_0>yellow-weed<b4_0/>.
